member.name: M:Graphviz4Net.Graphs.Graph`4.RemoveVertex(`0)
member.summary: Removes a vertex from this graph.

remarks.para: It cannot remove vertex from sub-graphs, for this one has to invoke specific method on sub-graph, if the sub-graph supports it.

To remove a vertex from sub-graph one has invoke RemoveVertex on that particular sub-graph. Class provides method , which is capable of removing a vertex from a sub-graph and which also removes all edges that contain the vertex.

member.param: Vertex to be removed.

member.summary: Removes given vertex and all related edges.

member.param: The vertex to be removed.

member.name: T:Graphviz4Net.ILayoutBuilder`1
member.summary: An interface for a class that builds the actual layout from information provided by the .

remarks.para: The object directs the whole process of creating the layout, when it has a piece of information about, e.g., a vertex position and size, it passes this piece of information to the builder, so the builder can create an actual vertex in the WPF Canvas, Windows Form, HTML/CSS files, ...

The director gets an original from the user, then it uses dot to create a layout for it -- this results into a new instance of the original graph, we will call it dot graph, that contains layout information. Most of the builder methods has an original graph element and then the dot graph element among their parameters.

Values generated by dot are passed to as they are. So the conversion must be done by the builder (each build will probably perform different kind of conversion). Dot used 2 axes X and Y. Position [0,0] is in the top, left corner and it increases to the right and to the bottom. Sizes (width, height) should be multiplied by 72 to have the same measure as positions.

member.name: M:Graphviz4Net.ILayoutBuilder`1.Start(Graphviz4Net.Graphs.IGraph)
member.summary: Starts the process of building a layout for the .
member.param: The original graph that should be laid out.

member.name: M:Graphviz4Net.ILayoutBuilder`1.BuildGraph(System.Double,System.Double,Graphviz4Net.Graphs.IGraph,Graphviz4Net.Dot.DotGraph{`0})
member.summary: Can be used to set up the size of a drawing area.
member.param: The with of the generated layout.
The height of the generated layout.
The original graph to be drawn.
The according generated dot graph with the layout information.

member.name: M:Graphviz4Net.ILayoutBuilder`1.BuildVertex(System.Windows.Point,System.Double,System.Double,System.Object,Graphviz4Net.Dot.DotVertex{`0})
member.summary: Builds a vertex provided with it's position and size, but also with the instance of the vertex in the original graph and instance of the vertex in graph generated by dot. (the position and size should be enough for most of layout builders)
member.param: The position of the vertex. Dot uses position coordinates incrementing from the top left corner.
The width of the vertex. Multiply this value by 72 to get the same measure as for .
The height of the vertex. Multiply this value by 72 to get the same measure as for .
The vertex from original graph that is to be drawn.
The according vertex with layout information generated by dot.

member.name: M:Graphviz4Net.ILayoutBuilder`1.BuildSubGraph(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,Graphviz4Net.Graphs.ISubGraph,Graphviz4Net.Dot.DotSubGraph{System.Int32})
member.summary: Builds a subgraph area provided with it's positions.
member.param: The subgraph from the original graph that is to be drawn.
The according subgraph with layout information generated by dot.

member.name: M:Graphviz4Net.ILayoutBuilder`1.BuildEdge(System.Windows.Point[],Graphviz4Net.Graphs.IEdge,Graphviz4Net.Dot.DotEdge{`0})
member.summary: Builds an edge provided with it's path. The path format is basically similar to the one used by WPF. See a dot manual for more detailed explanation.
member.remarks: Only a path of the edge is provided as a separate parameter, but the contains more layout information such as label position, or arrows positions. It depends upon the author of the builder whether he/she wants to support all these scenarios.

member.name: M:Graphviz4Net.ILayoutBuilder`1.Finish
member.summary: The last method called by when everything is done.

member.name: M:Graphviz4Net.ILayoutBuilder`1.GetSize(System.Object)
member.summary: Provides an expected size of given vertex so the dot knows how to layout this vertex. The size is measured as 1/72 of a point used for positions measure. (Just multiply it by 1/72)
member.param: The original vertex which should be measured.

member.name: M:Graphviz4Net.ILayoutBuilder`1.GetAdditionalAttributes(System.Object)
member.summary: Provides a way to add more attributes into the input file for dot, so the layouting process can be tweaked.

member.name: P:Graphviz4Net.Graphs.Edge`1.Weight

member.summary: Gets or sets the minimal space between the arrows on the boundary of the same node.

member.name: T:Graphviz4Net.LayoutDirector
member.summary: Directs the process of building a layout.

remarks.para: LayoutDirector delegates all the work to individual components, which are

The process of building a graph is divided up into three stages: , , . Only the and stages invokes the ; therefore, if the graph is built from GUI elements (e.g. WPF controls) these has to be run in the dispatcher thread. On contrary, the phase invokes only the method so, if this method can run outsize the dispatcher thread (e.g., one can calculate the size in advance), then the invocation of (the actual layouting, which might be slow) can be run in parallel.

member.name: M:Graphviz4Net.LayoutDirector.GetLayoutDirector(Graphviz4Net.ILayoutBuilder{System.Int32},Graphviz4Net.Dot.IDotParser{System.Int32},Graphviz4Net.Dot.IGraphToDotConverter,Graphviz4Net.IDotRunner)
member.summary: Factory method: provides convenient way to construct .

remarks.para: If an argument value is not provided (i.e., it's null), then default implementation of required interface is provided. See the documentation of the constructor of this class for the list of default implementations of these interfaces.

member.name: M:Graphviz4Net.LayoutDirector.#ctor(Graphviz4Net.ILayoutBuilder{System.Int32},Graphviz4Net.Dot.IDotParser{System.Int32},Graphviz4Net.Dot.IGraphToDotConverter,Graphviz4Net.IDotRunner)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The builder is responsible for building the actual graphical output.
The parser pases DOT output, default implementation is . Use factory method
The converter converts the .NET graph into a GraphViz representation. Default implementation is .
The dot runner runs the DOT utility. Default implementation is

member.name: M:Graphviz4Net.LayoutDirector.StartBuilder(Graphviz4Net.Graphs.IGraph)
member.summary: Starts the builder. If the builder requires to be run in the dispatcher thread, this method must be run in it.
member.param: The graph to be layouted.

member.name: M:Graphviz4Net.LayoutDirector.RunDot
member.summary: Runs the dot program and parses it's output. An invocation of must precede by a call to this method.
member.remarks: This method uses and , it does not invoke any method on . So in case the requires to run in dispatcher thread, this method does not have to do so, unless the or require it.

member.name: M:Graphviz4Net.LayoutDirector.BuildGraph
member.summary: Processes the graph parsed by and invokes methods on to build the actual layout. An invocation of must precede by a call to this method.

member.name: T:Graphviz4Net.Dot.DotVertex`1
member.summary: Represents a vertex in a obtained from an output of the DOT program.

remarks.para: A vertex can have any general Id type. If you want to use the whole process of layout building implemented in then under the hood, the vertices will have ids.
If you want to use only parsing abilities of Graphviz4Net, you can use the vertices with e.g. ids.

member.name: T:Graphviz4Net.Dot.AntlrParser.AntlrParserAdapter`1
member.summary: This adapter provides simple interface to the ANTLR parsing pipeline.

member.name: M:Graphviz4Net.Dot.AntlrParser.AntlrParserAdapter`1.GetParser
member.summary: Returns an instance of composed with graph builder for given type of node's ids. At the moment only and ids are supported.

remarks.para: Use as if you want arbitrary ids or support for 'node:record' syntax when defining edges. Use as if you want better performance, but in such case ids of nodes in your graph must be integral and 'node:record' syntax is not supported.
To implement custom builder, one must implement (or abstract class ) and use the other overload of this method.
